i can't see immediately if this covers all the cases above. what i do see is that you don't use + or -, so that code is not tested.
can we have, additional to this, something for sum, for times, for divide separated?

When trying to build tests for individual arithmetic operators, I actually found something interesting in our way of deducing division result precision and scale. I document it in the code.
But because of this special thing, I have to follow SQL Server's rules of reducing scale and cannot make it more strict. As a result, we lose scale digits more often and small error accumulates. A lot more tests fail now and I'm trying to get the results from SQL Server for those queries.

I end up with implementing SQL Server's scale reduction rules and fixing our result type precision/scale of division. In this way, TPC-H results are correct and only a few tests need to be adapted. Seems to be the best approach so far.
And separate tests on sum, times, and divide are added.
I think PLUS_OP should be added here similar to MINUS_OP.
Yes, it was a mistake. It should be PLUS_OP, not SUM_OP.
should it be rscale instead of rprec?

It seems that for the division precision and scale computation, the logic in getScale() and getPrecision() are not consistent.
In getPrecision():
			val = Math.min(maxPrecision,
						   this.getScale(operator, leftType, rightType) + lprec - lscale + rprec);

In getScale():
				val = Math.max(maxPrecision - lprec + lscale - rscale,
						MIN_DECIMAL_DIVIDE_SCALE);

I think the formula in getPrecision should be changed to
			val = Math.min(maxPrecision,
						   this.getScale(operator, leftType, rightType) + lprec - lscale + rscale);

to be consistent with getScale().

This is the mystery part and I think it was done like this on purpose. The idea seems to be always use maxPrecision for division and leave all free digits to scale. Let's take a closer look:
The way we get scale for division, is to calculate the number of digits needed for the integral part (lprec - lscale + rscale), and subtract it from maxPrecision. When getting precision, we add to scale a term lprec - lscale + rprec that is always GE than the integral part, so it will be always maxPrecision in the end. This change was done in implementing Decimal 38. The logic of getting scale for division was not like this, and we can see that from the old comment.
Changing the logic back to the old comment or the SQL server way causes quite many tests to fail, including TPCH ITs. I'm examining the failing tests one by one.

I finally get the root cause of test failures: SQL Server's MIN_DECIMAL_DIVIDE_SCALE = 6, but we set it to 4, and I was using 4 in multiplication case, too. That causes TPC-H queries return wrong results.
I fixed this part and also revert the logic of getPrecision() for division according to the old comment. Now only a few tests need to be adapted.

Right, this part basically promotes the precision to at least 34. If the determined scale is smaller than 4, then there would be some digits allowance for the integral part, thus total precision is further increased.
MIN_DECIMAL_MULTIPLICATION_SCALE should have no impact here. If the initial scale <= 6, say 3, then there will be no scale reduction in case of an multiplication. This part sees that there is 4-3=1 digit allowance for the integral part, and promote the type to (35,3), just as before this change.
If the initial scale was bigger than 6, we may reduce it but it would never be smaller than 6. Or we don't reduce it at all. In both cases, there would be no scale allowance. So if the initial precision was smaller than 34, final type would be (34,scale), otherwise it's (precision,scale).
Key idea is, when we reach this part, we know that we either have enough digits for integral part (scale reduced) or we cannot prevent overflow (scale untouched). In both cases, increasing precision do not affect correctness.
BUT!!!!!
This logic seems very strange to me. In my opinion, we should not blindly increase precision but to deduce it properly. If (20,8) is enough, then we should not increase it to (34,8).
